awd_titl_txt: CAS: Diastereoselective Polymerization Catalysis for Stereo-Sequenced Polymers with Biodegradability and Chemical Circularity
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Eugene Chen in the Department of Chemistry at Colorado State University. Professor Chen is designing catalyst systems for the synthesis of advanced polymeric materials that are biodegradable and chemically circular (can be deconstructed back into their component parts). The central goal of this program is to develop polymerization catalysts that can directly convert mixtures of monomer diastereomers (molecules that have the same bond connections but different three-dimensional structure) into new high-performance biodegradable materials with defined three-dimensional structure. Deconstruction of the polymers into fragments that can be joined back together into monomers is also being studied. This work is developing new catalytic processes for the atom- and energy-efficient synthesis of polymeric materials. The proposed research encompasses diverse areas of the chemical sciences, materials engineering, and sustainability, thereby providing an excellent opportunity for the training and teaching of students, including underrepresented and undergraduate students. This project also addresses the critical need to improve polymer recyclability and Professor Chen is emphasizing the importance of this sustainability issue in workshops, lectures, and presentations. 

New catalysts that can polymerize diastereomeric mixtures of monomers at any rac/meso ratio into stereo-sequenced polymers have the potential to transform the synthesis of high-performance crystalline materials. Diastereoselective polymerization not only avoids the material loss and added energy costs associated with diastereomeric pre-separation and purification required by traditional stereoselective polymerization methods, but also utilizes all of the diastereomers in a mixture to modulate material properties. This study is advancing diastereoselective polymerization catalysis to achieve direct polymerization of diastereomeric monomer mixtures into isotactic/syndiotactic stereo-sequenced biodegradable crystalline polymers. The approach involves designing diastereomer-selective and earth-abundant catalysts as well as examining catalyst structure–selectivity relationships via a combined experimental and theoretical approach. Furthermore, catalysis-enabled chemical circularity of the synthesized polymers is being developed to transform these materials back to their monomers, thus closing the loop of their life cycles. This program uses a rational catalyst/monomer design approach to advance polymeric materials and methodologies by emphasizing fundamental concepts related to ditacticity and diastereoselectivity. These studies serve as an excellent training ground for aspiring undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral chemists of diverse backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The central objective of the project is to advance the novel polymerization catalysis methodology termed diastereoselective polymerization that can directly convert diastereomeric monomer mixtures into new stereo-sequenced, crystalline high-performance poly(3-hydroxyalkanoate) (PHA) materials with both biodegradability and chemical circularity. The creation of this project was motivated by the following two considerations: the current method of polymerizing monomers bearing two or more stereogenic centers into stereoregular polymers requires diastereomer pre-separation/purification into racemic and meso isomers, thus accruing significant material loss and additional energy cost; and biodegradability in natural environments is the most unique property of PHAs, but currently there lack effective pathways for chemical recycling of PHAs to recover monomers that can be repolymerized back to virgin-quality PHAs towards a circular PHA economy. Accordingly, this project addresses these critical issues, aiming to achieve the following three major goals: (1) advancing diastereoselective polymerization of diastereomeric mixtures of bio-derived cyclic diolides into stereo-sequenced crystalline biodegradable PHAs; (2) examining molecular catalyst's structure–stereoselectivity/diastereoselectivity relationships in this polymerization; and (3) establishing chemical circularity of PHAs. This research has potential to positively impact our society, as this work utilizes catalytic polymerization methods for chemically recyclable and biodegradable polymer materials, the areas essential to the global economy, modern life, and environmental protection.

The research efforts centering on the above central objective and specific goals of the project have yielded four significant project results. (1) Diastereospecificity towards the polymerization of both rac- and meso-monomers, which produces highly isotactic and heterotactic polymers, respectively, has been achieved by an intramolecular chain shuttling mechanism enabled by the combination of an organic catalyst and an alkoxy salt activator. Mechanistic studies reveal an “Oscillatory Adaptive Catalysis” (OAC) phenomenon, which is the key to achieve dual recognition of the chirality of both the chain end and incoming monomer by using the two switchable chiral centers in catalyst. Such OAC enables dynamic interchange between chiral recognition (that triggers chain propagation) and stereochemical autocorrection (when monomer mismatched) by multi-site cooperativity, which induces chiral-site switching and polymer-chain shuttling intramolecularly within a single catalyst molecule. (2) Simple α,α-disubstitution in PHAs enhances the thermal and melt stability so substantially that the PHAs become melt-processable. Synergistically, this structural modification also endows the PHAs with the mechanical toughness, intrinsic crystallinity, and closed-loop chemical recyclability via both step-growth polymerization and ring-opening polymerization routes. (3) Stereo-defects present in stereoregular polymers often diminish thermal and mechanical properties, and thus suppressing or eliminating them is a major aspirational goal of achieving polymers with optimal or enhanced properties. Here, we accomplish the opposite: by introducing controlled stereo-defects to semicrystalline biodegradable poly(3-hydroxybutyrate) (P3HB), which offers an attractive biodegradable alternative to semicrystalline isotactic polypropylene but is brittle and opaque, we enhance specific properties and mechanical performance of P3HB by drastically toughening it and also rendering it with the desired optical clarity, while maintaining its biodegradability and crystallinity. (4) The chain ends of PHAs produced by step-growth polymerization determines the depolymerization selectivity toward 4- or 12-membered lactone formation, while both can be repolymerized back to PHA.

Key project's research findings have been disseminated to the scientific community and the general public through 15 peer-refereed publications acknowledging this NSF support, and through a number of seminars or lectures before academic, industrial, and international audiences. The current NSF support resulted in the employment, training and education of three female graduate students, two of whom have graduated with a Ph.D. degree and subsequently moved onto their independent careers after their respective postdoctoral research periods, and two postdoctoral research associates with technical skills needed for carrying out modern research in their future careers in chemical and materials sciences.


Last Modified: 11/11/2024
Modified by: Eugene Y Chen
